dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: A unanimous 8-0 Supreme Court decision just handed Oracle a massive victory over Google.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: A unanimous eight to zero Supreme Court decision just handed Oracle a massive victory over Google.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In a 6-to-2 outcome, the Supreme Courts justices rejected a lower court decision in Oracles favor, ruling instead that Googles copying of the pieces of code known as application programming interfaces, or APIs, was fair use.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and uh, Justice Samuel Alito really didn't hold back, did he? He called out Google's use of Java code in Android as a blatant copyright violation.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and uh, Justice Samuel Alito really didn't hold back, did he? He called out Google's use of Java code in Android as a blatant copyright violation.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In the dissenting opinion, Justice Thomas argued that Oracles code was copyrightable and that Googles use of it in Android was anything but fair.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and the ruling completely rejected the fair use argument—which, like, the court said was just promoting corporate greed in this instance.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, and the ruling completely rejected the fair use argument-which, like, the court said was just promoting corporate greed in this instance.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In a 6-to-2 outcome, the Supreme Courts justices rejected a lower court decision in Oracles favor, ruling instead that Googles copying of the pieces of code known as application programming interfaces, or APIs, was fair use. The fair use doctrine is designed to stop copyright protections from stifling innovation.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And Oracle was asking for $9 billion in damages, which honestly seems almost low given the scale of this.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And Oracle was asking for nine dollars billion in damages, which honestly seems almost low given the scale of this.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The ruling is a huge setback for Oracle, which had claimed up to $9 billion in damages for breach of its intellectual property.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: But wait, their CEO Larry Ellison was saying they actually did pay for the right to use those APIs? That's a huge contradiction.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But wait, their C E O Larry Ellison was saying they actually did pay for the right to use those APIs? That's a huge contradiction.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly, he seemed totally shaken up in that press conference, even suggesting bankruptcy might be imminent for Google.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly, he seemed totally shaken up in that press conference, even suggesting bankruptcy might be imminent for Google.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Which is wild, because we're talking about one of the biggest tech companies here. And now Oracle says it's discontinuing Android development?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which is wild, because we're talking about one of the biggest tech companies here. And now Oracle says it's discontinuing Android development?

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: That's the plan, apparently. They're the sole owner now. But wait, the text also said Android was a product of Apple? That can't be right.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That's the plan, apparently. They're the sole owner now. But wait, the text also said Android was a product of Apple? That can't be right.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Oracle alleged that Google had infringed its copyright when it copied some elements of code from Java, which is owned by Oracle, to build its Android operating system.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Oh yeah, that part's definitely confused—Android is Google's, not Apple's. Maybe a misstatement.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh yeah, that part's definitely confused-Android is Google's, not Apple's. Maybe a misstatement.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Oracle alleged that Google had infringed its copyright when it copied some elements of code from Java, which is owned by Oracle, to build its Android operating system.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And then there was that dissenting opinion from Justice Breyer, but he had to recuse himself because of alleged ties to tech companies?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And then there was that dissenting opinion from Justice Breyer, but he had to recuse himself because of alleged ties to tech companies?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The author of the majority opinion, Justice Stephen Breyer, wrote that Google had copied only what was needed to allow users to put their accrued talents to work in a new and transformative program.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it got pretty messy. But the majority ruling is being hailed as a huge win for copyright protection overall.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it got pretty messy. But the majority ruling is being hailed as a huge win for copyright protection overall.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Google said the courts opinion was a victory for consumers, interoperability and computer science, and that it gives legal certainty to the next generation of developers whose new products and services will benefit consumers.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Though I wonder how this will affect open-source projects moving forward. It sets a pretty strong precedent.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Though I wonder how this will affect open-source projects moving forward. It sets a pretty strong precedent.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Absolutely. And then it just randomly pivots to oil reserves at the end? "Houston, we have a problem?"
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Absolutely. And then it just randomly pivots to oil reserves at the end? Houston, we have a problem?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Houston, We Have A Problem. Oil Reserves Have Fallen Below 10 Years

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Right, like oil reserves falling below 10 years? That feels like it's pasted from a different article entirely.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, like oil reserves falling below ten years? That feels like it's pasted from a different article entirely.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Houston, We Have A Problem. Oil Reserves Have Fallen Below 10 Years

artist_script:
HostA: A unanimous 8-0 Supreme Court decision just handed Oracle a massive victory over Google.
HostB: Yeah, and uh, Justice Samuel Alito really didn’t hold back, did he? He called out Google’s use of Java code in Android as a blatant copyright violation.
HostA: Right, and the ruling completely rejected the fair use argument—which, like, the court said was just promoting corporate greed in this instance.
HostB: And Oracle was asking for $9 billion in damages, which honestly seems almost low given the scale of this.
HostA: But wait, their CEO Larry Ellison was saying they actually did pay for the right to use those APIs? That’s a huge contradiction.
HostB: Exactly, he seemed totally shaken up in that press conference, even suggesting bankruptcy might be imminent for Google.
HostA: Which is wild, because we’re talking about one of the biggest tech companies here. And now Oracle says it’s discontinuing Android development?
HostB: That’s the plan, apparently. They’re the sole owner now. But wait, the text also said Android was a product of Apple? That can’t be right.
HostA: Oh yeah, that part’s definitely confused—Android is Google’s, not Apple’s. Maybe a misstatement.
HostB: And then there was that dissenting opinion from Justice Breyer, but he had to recuse himself because of alleged ties to tech companies?
HostA: Yeah, it got pretty messy. But the majority ruling is being hailed as a huge win for copyright protection overall.
HostB: Though I wonder how this will affect open-source projects moving forward. It sets a pretty strong precedent.
HostA: Absolutely. And then it just randomly pivots to oil reserves at the end? "Houston, we have a problem?"
HostB: Right, like oil reserves falling below 10 years? That feels like it’s pasted from a different article entirely.
